All values are approximate.

The data for the 10 bars are as follows:

1900s: 200,000 migrants

1910s: 440,000 migrants

1920s: 810,000 migrants

1930s: 390,000 migrants

1940s: 1,450,000 migrants

1950s: 1,110,000 migrants

1960s: 1,000,000 migrants

1970s: 800,000 migrants

1980s: 600,000 migrants

1990s: 510,000 migrants
Adapted from James N. Gregory, America’s Great Migrations Project
content.question: Which of the following describes an effect of both the event depicted in the painting and a trend shown in the chart?

choices.label: Racial tensions in the South decreased as employers supported the migration of Black laborers from the region.
African Americans’ communities became predominantly rural as they relocated from cities to farmland.
Cities were transformed as African Americans infused the neighborhoods they settled with Black southern culture.
African Americans were given equal access to housing in the urban centers of the North, Midwest, and West.

content.answer: Cities were transformed as African Americans infused the neighborhoods they settled with Black southern culture.

skill.text: 1.C: Identify and explain patterns, connections, or other relationships (causation, changes, continuities, comparison).
